snippet.textDisplay:
I find it an interesting video, even though I really loved the film and it's soundtracks. It gives an interesting view of how the world of Avatar could shine on it's own. I don't know what really held the project of alien music back. Perhaps James Cameron wants to play it safe, perhaps the alien music really sounds like shit, or perhaps the project was just too ambitious, or probably all three, I would not know. I still do praise James Horner (Rest in Peace) with his skill to still come up with an overall very good soundtrack, even if it holds the sounds of different culture put together to sound different.

In my opinion, the story was good, with a very solid execution if not predictable. It is just your typical protagonist with a character arc where he turn's against the real invader as he falls in love of this new world, just like Dances with Wolves and The Last Samurai and even 2001 Atlantis: The Lost Empire. However the story was mostly build on its amezing setting and world building and it was all together by far the best cinema experience I have ever the pleasure to witness. The world building was fantastic, not only because it looked so overwhelmly beautiful and cool, but it looked like a complex functional ecosystem populated by exotic plants and animals with believable traits like how it works in a natural ecosystem in our world.


I am still amazed how much the film got hated by people that did not buy it because it was so generic. In my experience, the overal credibility in the story, the lore, a well characterization of the personages and what they stand for, with a solid execution could still make very good experience even if the story is done before. In the end it is only your decision wheter you allow yourself to enjoy fiction with a story that has been used before, just like 2000 'Dinosaur' is a rehashed story of 'The Land Before Time' or 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' is a rehashed story of 'Star Wars: A New Hope'.If not you basically saying you have a higher niche in fiction, which is fine, just don't come across as a hypocrite, but hey it is all about finding the match that satisfy your personal experience.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: (i'm still at the beginning of the video) that's why I love Avatar : not because of the cliche scenario, but only for the worldbuilding behind. I mean, I had the same book about the lore of avatar, and it was my very first iteration to what "worldbuilding" is. So yeah, I might be one of the only peoples on this planet that still remember and like Avatar, and I cant wait to see the sequels.

snippet.textDisplay:
Two Steps from hell cannot beat or compete with this Movie's music from your explanation.
Meanwhile here I am making my own IN EXACTLY the same way it was done in this movie, but I have never heard how it was done to begin with. I'm a one man team making a short for a 3d animated film. It's absolutely blown my mind how we have similar approaches to music and lore.

snippet.textDisplay: Apparently this guy doesn't know as much about cinema as he implies. You need your audience to respond to what's in your movie. It needs to be at least partially familiar. If nobody wants to watch your movie then there's no point in making it. And stop acting like you're offended that a fake culture of aliens wasn't properly represented through their music which was commissioned by the film maker in the first place. Those are some first world problems you've got there.

snippet.textDisplay: I think what you're not getting is, you have to experiment and then throw out what doesn't work.  You can't always know beforehand whether you might not discover something really cool that sounds both alien and relatable.  If you do this kind of world-building stuff then, yes, a lot of it is never used in a single movie.  That's just the way this goes.
snippet.textOriginal: I think what you're not getting is, you have to experiment and then throw out what doesn't work.  You can't always know beforehand whether you might not discover something really cool that sounds both alien and relatable.  If you do this kind of world-building stuff then, yes, a lot of it is never used in a single movie.  That's just the way this goes.

snippet.authorDisplayName: That One Cat with the Top Hat
snippet.textDisplay:
That sucks that they wasted so much money to make a soundtrack, only to completely discard it. If they didn't use it on the money, they should have used it at least a little bit on the story and not the canon. Honestly, the movie has fantastic worldbuilding and CGI, but it's really lacking in terms of story and that frustrates me a lot. The fact that they wasted a soundtrack on top of that only frustrates me more.

I want them to release that soundtrack.
snippet.textOriginal:
That sucks that they wasted so much money to make a soundtrack, only to completely discard it. If they didn't use it on the money, they should have used it at least a little bit on the story and not the canon. Honestly, the movie has fantastic worldbuilding and CGI, but it's really lacking in terms of story and that frustrates me a lot. The fact that they wasted a soundtrack on top of that only frustrates me more.

I want them to release that soundtrack.

snippet.textDisplay: There's no doubt to me that the Avatar soundtrack was good because of one heck of a film composer that they had, but man hearing about what it could have been! snippet.textDisplay: A friend of mine once complained that Avatar's score got snubbed at the Oscars by Pixar's Up.  To paraphrase, "Up's just the same theme reorchestrated over and over again."  I always felt he was being ignorant to how many emotions Michael Giacchino successfully wrung out of that one leitmotif and I could never get the same sentimental attachment to Avatar's soundtrack.  Now, in a strange way, I feel like my subjective taste in music has been objectively validated.
snippet.textOriginal: A friend of mine once complained that Avatar's score got snubbed at the Oscars by Pixar's Up.  To paraphrase, "Up's just the same theme reorchestrated over and over again."  I always felt he was being ignorant to how many emotions Michael Giacchino successfully wrung out of that one leitmotif and I could never get the same sentimental attachment to Avatar's soundtrack.  Now, in a strange way, I feel like my subjective taste in music has been objectively validated.
